page.content:
Goals for this Course

  • Provide local program administrators with the theory, tools, and strategies to design, fund, implement, and evaluate a bridge program for continued student success.
  • Advance the design, delivery, and outcomes of adult career pathways by enhancing opportunities for contextualized teaching and learning through bridge programs designed to move low-skilled adults into further training and employment.
Course Description

The main purpose of this course is to support adult education and basic skills remediation programs in developing effective transition programs that meet the multifaceted and complex needs of post-traditional students. Participants will be able to identify core elements of successful transition programming, develop and apply appropriate organizational strategies for designing a bridge program framework that meets labor market demand, and provide access for students with various skill levels through a model that can be applied to multiple sectors. Embedded in the bridge framework is academic and career support that can lead to employment in high-demand jobs.


Course Objectives

Upon completion of this course, participants will be able to:

  • Define a bridge program and understand how it aligns with adult career pathways
  • Identify the essential components of a successful bridge program
  • Describe how to fund a bridge program
  • Develop and market a bridge program using a framework
  • Identify the three models of a comprehensive evaluation
  • Plan for program sustainability
  • Use a framework to implement the steps necessary to develop a bridge program
Course Organization

The course is organized into six units, followed by a capstone activity: building a bridge program using a framework.

  1. Defining Bridge Programs
  2. Essential Components of a Bridge Program
  3. Funding a Bridge Program
  4. Marketing the Bridge Program
  5. Evaluating the Bridge Program
  6. Sustaining and Scaling the Bridge Program
